unity_academy.label: get_main_camera_following_target
unity_academy.title: Auto-import from unity_academy
unity_academy.description:
#### get_main_camera_following_target() → GameObjectIdentifier
Get the main camera following target GameObject (an invisible GameObject) to use it to control the position of the main camera with the default camera controller.

* **In 3D mode**, the default camera controller behaves as third-person camera controller, and the center to follow is the following target GameObject. Also, Unity Academy will automatically set the rotation of this "following target" to the same rotation as the current main camera's rotation to let you get the main camera's rotation.
* **In 2D mode**, the default camera controller will follow the target GameObject to move, along with a position delta value that you can adjust with the arrow keys on your keyboard.

The main camera following target GameObject is a primitive GameObject. This means that you are not allowed to destroy it and/or instantiate it during runtime. Multiple calls to this function will return GameObject identifiers that refer to the same primitive GameObject.

**If default main camera controllers are disabled (you have called `request_for_main_camera_control`), then the following target GameObject is useless.**

unity_academy.description:
#### gui_label(text, x, y) → void
Draw a text (string) on the screen with given **screen space position** in the current frame.

The origin of screen space is upper-left corner and the positive Y direction is downward.

The drawn text will only last for one frame. You should put this under the `Update` function (or a function that is called by the `Update` function) to keep the text stays in every frame.

You can use rich text for the parameter `text`. For example: `gui_label("<color=#AA00FF>Hello World</color>", 100, 100);`

The Sprite GameObject has a BoxCollider2D that matches its size by default. You may use `remove_collider_components` function to remove the default collider.

Note that Unity Academy will use a HTTP GET request to download the image, which means that the HTTP response from the URL must allows CORS.

**2D mode only**

unity_academy.label: on_collision_enter
unity_academy.title: Auto-import from unity_academy
unity_academy.description:
#### on_collision_enter(gameObjectIdentifier, eventFunction) → void
Set the lifecycle event function that will be called when the collider on this GameObject just starting colliding with another collider.

The given function should contain two parameters. The first parameter refers to the binded GameObject and the second parameter refers to the other GameObject that collides with the binded GameObject (both parameters are GameObject identifiers).

For example: `const myFunction = (self, other) => {...};`

* Note that for collision detaction to happen, for the two colliding GameObjects:
  + if **in 3D mode**, both GameObjects must applied Rigidbody by `apply_rigidbody`
  + if **in 2D mode**, at least one GameObject must applied Rigidbody by `apply_rigidbody`

For more information, see

* https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Collider.OnCollisionEnter.html (For 3D Mode)
* https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/MonoBehaviour.OnCollisionEnter2D.html (For 2D Mode)

unity_academy.label: on_collision_exit
unity_academy.title: Auto-import from unity_academy
unity_academy.description:
#### on_collision_exit(gameObjectIdentifier, eventFunction) → void
Set the lifecycle event function that will be called when the collider on this GameObject just stops colliding with another collider.

The given function should contain two parameters. The first parameter refers to the binded GameObject and the second parameter refers to the other GameObject that collides with the binded GameObject (both parameters are GameObject identifiers).

For example: `const myFunction = (self, other) => {...};`

* Note that for collision detaction to happen, for the two colliding GameObjects:
  + if **in 3D mode**, both GameObjects must applied Rigidbody by `apply_rigidbody`
  + if **in 2D mode**, at least one GameObject must applied Rigidbody by `apply_rigidbody`

For more information, see

* https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/MonoBehaviour.OnCollisionExit.html (For 3D Mode)
* https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/MonoBehaviour.OnCollisionExit2D.html (For 2D Mode)

unity_academy.label: on_collision_stay
unity_academy.title: Auto-import from unity_academy
unity_academy.description:
#### on_collision_stay(gameObjectIdentifier, eventFunction) → void
Set the lifecycle event function that will be called per frame when the collider on this GameObject is colliding with another collider.

The given function should contain two parameters. The first parameter refers to the binded GameObject and the second parameter refers to the other GameObject that collides with the binded GameObject (both parameters are GameObject identifiers).

For example: `const myFunction = (self, other) => {...};`

* Note that for collision detaction to happen, for the two colliding GameObjects:
  + if **in 3D mode**, both GameObjects must applied Rigidbody by `apply_rigidbody`
  + if **in 2D mode**, at least one GameObject must applied Rigidbody by `apply_rigidbody`

For more information, see

* https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/Collider.OnCollisionStay.html (For 3D Mode)
* https://docs.unity3d.com/ScriptReference/MonoBehaviour.OnCollisionStay2D.html (For 2D Mode)

unity_academy.label: request_for_main_camera_control
unity_academy.title: Auto-import from unity_academy
unity_academy.description:
#### request_for_main_camera_control() → GameObjectIdentifier
Request for main camera control and get a GameObject identifier that can directly be used to control the main camera's position and rotation.

When you request for the direct control over main camera with this function, the default camera controllers will be disabled, thus the GameObject identifier returned by `get_main_camera_following_target` will become useless, as you can no longer use the default main camera controllers.

This function is for totally customizing the position and rotation of the main camera. If you'd like to simplify the camera controlling with the help of the default camera controllers in Unity Academy, please consider use `get_main_camera_following_target` function.

pix_n_flix.label: install_filter
pix_n_flix.title: Auto-import from pix_n_flix
pix_n_flix.description:
#### install_filter(_filter) → void
Installs the given filter to be used to transform each source image from
the live camera or from a local/remote file to a destination image that
is then displayed on screen.

A filter is a function that is applied to two
two-dimensional arrays of Pixels:
the source image and the destination image.

pix_n_flix.title: Auto-import from pix_n_flix
pix_n_flix.description:

Sets pix\_n\_flix to preserve the aspect ratio of the video or image

pix_n_flix.label: pause_at
pix_n_flix.title: Auto-import from pix_n_flix
pix_n_flix.description:
#### pause_at(pause_time) → void
Pauses the video at a set time after the video starts.

pix_n_flix.label: red_of
pix_n_flix.title: Auto-import from pix_n_flix
pix_n_flix.description:
#### red_of(pixel) → number

pix_n_flix.label: reset_filter
pix_n_flix.title: Auto-import from pix_n_flix
pix_n_flix.description:
#### reset_filter() → void

pix_n_flix.label: set_dimensions
pix_n_flix.title: Auto-import from pix_n_flix
pix_n_flix.description:
#### set_dimensions(width, height) → void
Sets the diemsions of the displayed images.
Note: Only accepts width and height values within the range of 1 to 500.

pix_n_flix.label: set_fps
pix_n_flix.title: Auto-import from pix_n_flix
pix_n_flix.description:
#### set_fps(fps) → void
Sets the framerate (i.e. frames per second (FPS)) of the video.
Note: Only accepts FPS values within the range of 2 to 30.

pix_n_flix.label: set_loop_count
pix_n_flix.title: Auto-import from pix_n_flix
pix_n_flix.description:

If the number of times the video repeats is negative, the video will loop forever.

pix_n_flix.label: set_rgba
pix_n_flix.title: Auto-import from pix_n_flix
pix_n_flix.description:
#### set_rgba(pixel, r, g, b, a) → void

the given pixel.

pix_n_flix.label: set_volume
pix_n_flix.title: Auto-import from pix_n_flix
pix_n_flix.description:
#### set_volume(volume) → void
Sets the audio volume of the local video file played.
Note: Only accepts volume value within the range of 0 to 100.

pix_n_flix.label: start
pix_n_flix.title: Auto-import from pix_n_flix
pix_n_flix.description:

Starts processing the image or video using the installed filter.

pix_n_flix.description:

Sets pix\_n\_flix to use the image from the given URL as the image feed

pix_n_flix.description:

Sets pix\_n\_flix to use the video from the given URL as the video feed
instead of using the default live camera feed.

curve.label: animate_3D_curve
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### animate_3D_curve(duration, fps, drawer, func) → AnimatedCurve
Create a animation of curves using a curve generating function.

curve.label: animate_curve
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### animate_curve(duration, fps, drawer, func) → AnimatedCurve
Create a animation of curves using a curve generating function.

curve.label: arc
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### arc(t) → Point
This function is a curve: a function from a fraction t to a point. The points
lie on the right half of the unit circle. They start at Point (0,1) when t is

0. When t is 0.5, they reach Point (1,0), when t is 1, they reach Point
   (0, -1).

curve.label: b_of
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### b_of(pt) → number
Retrieves the blue component of a given Point.

curve.label: connect_ends
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### connect_ends(curve1, curve2) → Curve
This function is a binary Curve operator: It takes two Curves as arguments
and returns a new Curve. The two Curves are combined by using the full first
Curve for the first portion of the result and by using the full second Curve
for the second portion of the result. The second Curve is translated such
that its point at fraction 0 is the same as the Point of the first Curve at
fraction 1.

curve.label: connect_rigidly
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### connect_rigidly(curve1, curve2) → Curve
This function is a binary Curve operator: It takes two Curves as arguments
and returns a new Curve. The two Curves are combined by using the full first
Curve for the first portion of the result and by using the full second Curve
for the second portion of the result. The second Curve is not changed, and
therefore there might be a big jump in the middle of the result Curve.

curve.label: draw_3D_connected
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### draw_3D_connected(numPoints) → RenderFunction
Returns a function that turns a given 3D Curve into a Drawing, by sampling
the 3D Curve at `num` sample points and connecting each pair with
a line. The parts between (0,0,0) and (1,1,1) of the resulting Drawing are
shown within the unit cube.

curve.label: draw_3D_connected_full_view
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### draw_3D_connected_full_view(numPoints) → RenderFunction
Returns a function that turns a given 3D Curve into a Drawing, by sampling
the 3D Curve at `num` sample points and connecting each pair with
a line. The Drawing is translated and stretched/shrunk to show the full
curve and maximize its width and height within the cube.

curve.label: draw_3D_connected_full_view_proportional
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### draw_3D_connected_full_view_proportional(numPoints) → RenderFunction
Returns a function that turns a given 3D Curve into a Drawing, by sampling
the 3D Curve at `num` sample points and connecting each pair with
a line. The Drawing is translated and scaled proportionally with its size
maximized to fit entirely inside the cube.

curve.label: draw_3D_points
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### draw_3D_points(numPoints) → RenderFunction
Returns a function that turns a given 3D Curve into a Drawing, by sampling
the 3D Curve at `num` sample points. The Drawing consists of
isolated points, and does not connect them. The parts between (0,0,0)
and (1,1,1) of the resulting Drawing are shown within the unit cube.

curve.label: draw_3D_points_full_view
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### draw_3D_points_full_view(numPoints) → RenderFunction
Returns a function that turns a given 3D Curve into a Drawing, by sampling
the 3D Curve at `num` sample points. The Drawing consists of
isolated points, and does not connect them. The Drawing is translated and
stretched/shrunk to maximize its size to fit entirely inside the cube.

curve.label: draw_3D_points_full_view_proportional
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### draw_3D_points_full_view_proportional(numPoints) → RenderFunction
Returns a function that turns a given 3D Curve into a Drawing, by sampling
the 3D Curve at `num` sample points. The Drawing consists of
isolated points, and does not connect them. The Drawing is translated and
scaled proportionally with its size maximized to fit entirely inside the cube.

curve.label: draw_connected
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### draw_connected(numPoints) → RenderFunction
Returns a function that turns a given Curve into a Drawing, by sampling the
Curve at `num` sample points and connecting each pair with a line.
The parts between (0,0) and (1,1) of the resulting Drawing are shown in the window.

curve.label: draw_connected_full_view
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### draw_connected_full_view(numPoints) → RenderFunction
Returns a function that turns a given Curve into a Drawing, by sampling the
Curve at `num` sample points and connecting each pair with a line. The Drawing is
translated and stretched/shrunk to show the full curve and maximize its width
and height, with some padding.

curve.label: draw_connected_full_view_proportional
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### draw_connected_full_view_proportional(numPoints) → RenderFunction
Returns a function that turns a given Curve into a Drawing, by sampling the
Curve at `num` sample points and connecting each pair with a line. The Drawing
is translated and scaled proportionally to show the full curve and maximize
its size, with some padding.

curve.label: draw_points
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### draw_points(numPoints) → RenderFunction
Returns a function that turns a given Curve into a Drawing, by sampling the
Curve at `num` sample points. The Drawing consists of isolated
points, and does not connect them. The parts between (0,0) and (1,1) of the
resulting Drawing are shown in the window.

curve.label: draw_points_full_view
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### draw_points_full_view(numPoints) → RenderFunction
Returns a function that turns a given Curve into a Drawing, by sampling the
Curve at `num` sample points. The Drawing consists of isolated
points, and does not connect them. The Drawing is translated and
stretched/shrunk to show the full curve and maximize its width and height,
with some padding.

curve.label: draw_points_full_view_proportional
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### draw_points_full_view_proportional(numPoints) → RenderFunction
Returns a function that turns a given Curve into a Drawing, by sampling the
Curve at `num` sample points. The Drawing consists of isolated
points, and does not connect them. The Drawing is translated and scaled
proportionally with its size maximized to fit entirely inside the window,
with some padding.

curve.label: g_of
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### g_of(pt) → number
Retrieves the green component of a given Point.

curve.label: invert
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### invert(curve) → Curve
This function is a Curve transformation: a function from a Curve to a Curve.
The points of the result Curve are the same points as the points of the
original Curve, but in reverse: The result Curve applied to 0 is the original
Curve applied to 1 and vice versa.

curve.label: make_3D_color_point
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### make_3D_color_point(x, y, z, r, g, b) → Point
Makes a 3D color Point with given x, y and z coordinates, and RGB values
ranging from 0 to 255. Any input lower than 0 for RGB will be rounded up to
0, and any input higher than 255 will be rounded down to 255.

curve.label: make_3D_point
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### make_3D_point(x, y, z) → Point
Makes a 3D Point with given x, y and z coordinates.

curve.label: make_color_point
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### make_color_point(x, y, r, g, b) → Point
Makes a color Point with given x and y coordinates, and RGB values ranging
from 0 to 255. Any input lower than 0 for RGB will be rounded up to 0, and
any input higher than 255 will be rounded down to 255.

curve.label: make_point
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### make_point(x, y) → Point
Makes a Point with given x and y coordinates.

curve.label: put_in_standard_position
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### put_in_standard_position(curve) → Curve
This function is a Curve transformation: It takes a Curve as argument and
returns a new Curve, as follows. A Curve is in standard position if it
starts at (0,0) ends at (1,0). This function puts the given Curve in
standard position by rigidly translating it so its start Point is at the
origin (0,0), then rotating it about the origin to put its endpoint on the
x axis, then scaling it to put the endpoint at (1,0). Behavior is unspecified
on closed Curves where start-point equal end-point.

curve.label: r_of
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### r_of(pt) → number
Retrieves the red component of a given Point.

curve.label: rotate_around_origin
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### rotate_around_origin(theta1, theta2, theta3) → CurveTransformer
This function takes 3 angles, a, b and c in radians as parameter
and returns a Curve transformation: a function that takes a Curve as argument
and returns a new Curve, which is the original Curve rotated
extrinsically with Euler angles (a, b, c) about x, y,
and z axes.

curve.label: scale
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### scale(a, b, c) → CurveTransformer
This function takes scaling factors `a`, `b` and
`c`, as arguments and returns a
Curve transformation that scales a given Curve by `a` in
x-direction, `b` in y-direction and `c` in z-direction.

curve.label: scale_proportional
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### scale_proportional(s) → CurveTransformer
This function takes a scaling factor s argument and returns a Curve
transformation that scales a given Curve by s in x, y and z direction.

curve.label: translate
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### translate(x0, y0, z0) → CurveTransformer
This function returns a Curve transformation: It takes an x-value x0, a
y-value y0 and a z-value z0, as arguments and
returns a Curve transformation that takes a Curve as argument and returns a
new Curve, by translating the original by x0 in x-direction, y0 in
y-direction and z0 in z-direction.

curve.label: unit_circle
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### unit_circle(t) → Point
This function is a curve: a function from a fraction t to a point. The points
lie on the unit circle. They start at Point (1,0) when t is 0. When t is
0.25, they reach Point (0,1), when t is 0.5, they reach Point (-1, 0), etc.

curve.label: unit_line
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### unit_line(t) → Point
This function is a curve: a function from a fraction t to a point. The
x-coordinate at fraction t is t, and the y-coordinate is 0.

curve.label: unit_line_at
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### unit_line_at(t) → Curve
This function is a Curve generator: it takes a number and returns a
horizontal curve. The number is a y-coordinate, and the Curve generates only
points with the given y-coordinate.

curve.label: x_of
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### x_of(pt) → number
Retrieves the x-coordinate of a given Point.

curve.label: y_of
curve.title: Auto-import from curve
curve.description:
#### y_of(pt) → number
Retrieves the y-coordinate of a given Point.

curve.label: z_of

curve.description:

Retrieves the z-coordinate of a given Point.

sound.label: adsr
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### adsr(attack_ratio, decay_ratio, sustain_level, release_ratio) → SoundTransformer
Returns an envelope: a function from Sound to Sound.
When the adsr envelope is applied to a Sound, it returns
a new Sound with its amplitude modified according to parameters
The relative amplitude increases from 0 to 1 linearly over the
attack proportion, then decreases from 1 to sustain level over the
decay proportion, and remains at that level until the release
proportion when it decays back to 0.

sound.label: bell
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### bell(note, duration) → Sound
returns a Sound reminiscent of a bell, playing
a given note for a given duration

sound.label: cello
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### cello(note, duration) → Sound
returns a Sound reminiscent of a cello, playing
a given note for a given duration

sound.label: consecutively
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### consecutively(list_of_sounds) → Sound
Makes a new Sound by combining the sounds in a given list
where the second Sound is appended to the end of the first Sound,
the third Sound is appended to the end of the second Sound, and
so on. The effect is that the Sounds in the list are joined end-to-end

sound.label: get_duration
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### get_duration(sound) → number
Accesses the duration of a given Sound.

sound.label: get_wave
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### get_wave(sound) → Wave
Accesses the wave function of a given Sound.

sound.label: init_record
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### init_record() → string
Initialize recording by obtaining permission
to use the default device microphone

sound.label: is_sound
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### is_sound(x) → x is Sound
Checks if the argument is a Sound

sound.label: letter_name_to_frequency
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### letter_name_to_frequency(note) → number
Converts a letter name to its corresponding frequency.

sound.label: letter_name_to_midi_note
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### letter_name_to_midi_note(note) → number
Converts a letter name to its corresponding MIDI note.
The letter name is represented in standard pitch notation.
Examples are "A5", "Db3", "C#7".
Refer to <a href="https://i.imgur.com/qGQgmYr.png">this mapping from
letter name to midi notes.

sound.label: make_sound
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### make_sound(wave, duration) → Sound
Makes a Sound with given wave function and duration.
The wave function is a function: number -> number
that takes in a non-negative input time and returns an amplitude
between -1 and 1.

sound.label: midi_note_to_frequency
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### midi_note_to_frequency(note) → number
Converts a MIDI note to its corresponding frequency.

sound.label: noise_sound
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### noise_sound(duration) → Sound
Makes a noise Sound with given duration

sound.label: phase_mod
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### phase_mod(freq, duration, amount) → SoundTransformer
Returns a Sound transformer which uses its argument
to modulate the phase of a (carrier) sine wave
of given frequency and duration with a given Sound.
Modulating with a low frequency Sound results in a vibrato effect.
Modulating with a Sound with frequencies comparable to
the sine wave frequency results in more complex wave forms.

sound.label: piano
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### piano(note, duration) → Sound
returns a Sound reminiscent of a piano, playing
a given note for a given duration

sound.label: play
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### play(sound) → Sound
Plays the given Sound using the computer’s sound device
on top of any Sounds that are currently playing.

sound.label: play_in_tab
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### play_in_tab(sound) → Sound
Plays the given Sound using the computer’s sound device.
The sound is added to a list of sounds to be played one-at-a-time
in a Source Academy tab.

sound.label: play_wave
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### play_wave(wave, duration) → Sound
Plays the given Wave using the computer’s sound device, for the duration
given in seconds.

sound.label: record
sound.title: Auto-import from sound

sound.label: record_for
sound.title: Auto-import from sound

sound.label: sawtooth_sound
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:

sound.label: silence_sound
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### silence_sound(duration) → Sound
Makes a silence Sound with given duration

sound.label: simultaneously
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### simultaneously(list_of_sounds) → Sound
Makes a new Sound by combining the Sounds in a given list.
In the result sound, the component sounds overlap such that
they start at the beginning of the result sound. To achieve
this, the amplitudes of the component sounds are added together
and then divided by the length of the list.

sound.label: sine_sound
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### sine_sound(freq, duration) → Sound
Makes a sine wave Sound with given frequency and duration

sound.label: square_sound
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### square_sound(f, duration) → Sound
Makes a square wave Sound with given frequency and duration

sound.label: stacking_adsr
sound.title: Auto-import from sound
sound.description:
#### stacking_adsr(waveform, base_frequency, duration, envelopes) → Sound
Returns a Sound that results from applying a list of envelopes
to a given wave form. The wave form is a Sound generator that
takes a frequency and a duration as arguments and produces a
Sound with the given frequency and duration. Each envelope is
applied to a harmonic: the first harmonic has the given frequency,
the second has twice the frequency, the third three times the
frequency etc. The harmonics are then layered simultaneously to
produce the resulting Sound.

#### scrabble_letters:string[][]
`scrabble_letters` is an array of arrays of strings. Each array

the letters of that word as single-character strings in the
order in which the letters appear in the word.

stereo_sound.label: adsr
stereo_sound.title: Auto-import from stereo_sound
stereo_sound.description:
#### adsr(attack_ratio, decay_ratio, sustain_level, release_ratio) → SoundTransformer
Returns an envelope: a function from Sound to Sound.
When the adsr envelope is applied to a Sound, it returns
a new Sound with its amplitude modified according to parameters
The relative amplitude increases from 0 to 1 linearly over the
attack proportion, then decreases from 1 to sustain level over the
decay proportion, and remains at that level until the release
proportion when it decays back to 0.

stereo_sound.title: Auto-import from stereo_sound
stereo_sound.description:

stereo_sound.label: consecutively
stereo_sound.title: Auto-import from stereo_sound
stereo_sound.description:
#### consecutively(list_of_sounds) → Sound
Makes a new Sound by combining the sounds in a given list
where the second sound is appended to the end of the first sound,
the third sound is appended to the end of the second sound, and
so on. The effect is that the sounds in the list are joined end-to-end

stereo_sound.label: letter_name_to_midi_note
stereo_sound.title: Auto-import from stereo_sound
stereo_sound.description:
#### letter_name_to_midi_note(note) → number
Converts a letter name to its corresponding MIDI note.
The letter name is represented in standard pitch notation.
Examples are "A5", "Db3", "C#7".
Refer to <a href="https://i.imgur.com/qGQgmYr.png">this mapping from
letter name to midi notes.

stereo_sound.label: make_sound
stereo_sound.title: Auto-import from stereo_sound
stereo_sound.description:
#### make_sound(wave, duration) → Sound
Makes a Sound with given wave function and duration.
The wave function is a function: number -> number
that takes in a non-negative input time and returns an amplitude
between -1 and 1.

stereo_sound.label: make_stereo_sound
stereo_sound.title: Auto-import from stereo_sound
stereo_sound.description:
#### make_stereo_sound(left_wave, right_wave, duration) → Sound
Makes a Stereo Sound with given wave function and duration.
The wave function is a function: number -> number
that takes in a non-negative input time and returns an amplitude
between -1 and 1.

stereo_sound.label: midi_note_to_frequency
stereo_sound.title: Auto-import from stereo_sound
stereo_sound.description:
#### midi_note_to_frequency(note) → number

stereo_sound.label: noise_sound
stereo_sound.title: Auto-import from stereo_sound
stereo_sound.description:
#### noise_sound(duration) → Sound
Makes a noise sound with given duration

stereo_sound.label: pan
stereo_sound.title: Auto-import from stereo_sound
stereo_sound.description:
#### pan(amount) → SoundTransformer
Returns a Sound Transformer that pans a sound based on the pan amount.
The input sound is first squashed to mono.
An amount of `-1` is a hard left pan, `0` is balanced, `1` is hard right pan.

stereo_sound.label: pan_mod
stereo_sound.title: Auto-import from stereo_sound
stereo_sound.description:
#### pan_mod(modulator) → SoundTransformer
Returns a Sound Transformer that uses a Sound to pan another Sound.
The modulator is treated as a mono sound and its output is used to pan
an input Sound.
`-1` is a hard left pan, `0` is balanced, `1` is hard right pan.

stereo_sound.label: phase_mod
stereo_sound.title: Auto-import from stereo_sound
stereo_sound.description:
#### phase_mod(freq, duration, amount) → SoundTransformer
Returns a SoundTransformer which uses its argument
to modulate the phase of a (carrier) sine wave
of given frequency and duration with a given Sound.
Modulating with a low frequency Sound results in a vibrato effect.
Modulating with a Sound with frequencies comparable to
the sine wave frequency results in more complex wave forms.

stereo_sound.label: piano
stereo_sound.title: Auto-import from stereo_sound
stereo_sound.description:
#### piano(note, duration) → Sound
returns a Sound reminiscent of a piano, playing
a given note for a given duration

stereo_sound.label: play
stereo_sound.title: Auto-import from stereo_sound
stereo_sound.description:
#### play(sound) → Sound
Plays the given Sound using the computer’s sound device

stereo_sound.label: play_in_tab

stereo_sound.description:

The Sound is added to a list of Sounds to be played one-at-a-time

stereo_sound.label: play_wave

stereo_sound.label: play_waves

stereo_sound.description:
#### play_waves(wave1, wave2, duration) → Sound
Plays the given two Waves using the computer’s sound device, for the duration
given in seconds. The first Wave is for the left channel, the second for the
right channel.

game.label: add
game.title: Auto-import from game
game.description:
#### add(obj) → GameObject | undefined
Add the object to the scene. Only objects added to the scene
will appear.

game.label: add_keyboard_listener
game.title: Auto-import from game
game.description:
#### add_keyboard_listener(key, event, callback) → GameObject
Attach a listener to the object. The callback will be executed
when the event is emitted.
Mutate the object.

For all available events, see:
https://photonstorm.github.io/phaser3-docs/Phaser.Input.Events.html

For list of keycodes, see:
https://github.com/photonstorm/phaser/blob/v3.22.0/src/input/keyboard/keys/KeyCodes.js

game.title: Auto-import from game

game.label: add_to_container
game.title: Auto-import from game
game.description:

Mutates the container.

game.label: add_tween
game.title: Auto-import from game
game.description:
#### add_tween(obj, config) → Promise<GameObject | undefined>
Creates a tween to the object and plays it.
Mutate the object.

game.label: create_anim
game.title: Auto-import from game
game.description:
#### create_anim(anim_config) → boolean
Create a new animation and add it to the available animations.
Animations are global i.e. once created, it can be used anytime, anywhere.

NOTE: Anims DO NOT need to be added into the scene to be used.
It is automatically added to the scene when it is created.

Will return true if the animation key is valid
(key is specified within the anim\_config); false if the key
is already in use.

game.label: create_anim_config
game.title: Auto-import from game
game.description:
#### create_anim_config(anims_key, anim_frames, frame_rate, duration, repeat, yoyo, show_on_start, hide_on_complete) → ObjectConfig
Create anims config, can be used to configure anims

For more details about the config object, see:
https://photonstorm.github.io/phaser3-docs/Phaser.Types.Animations.html#.Animation

game.label: create_anim_frame_config
game.title: Auto-import from game
game.description:
#### create_anim_frame_config(key, duration, visible) → ObjectConfig
Create animation frame config, can be used to configure a specific frame
within an animation.

The key should refer to an image that is already loaded.
To make frame\_config from spritesheet based on its frames,
use create\_anim\_spritesheet\_frame\_configs instead.

game.label: create_anim_spritesheet_frame_configs
game.title: Auto-import from game
game.description:
#### create_anim_spritesheet_frame_configs(key) → ObjectConfig[] | undefined
Create list of animation frame config, can be used directly as part of
anim\_config's `frames` parameter.

This function will generate list of frame configs based on the
spritesheet\_config attached to the associated spritesheet.
This function requires that the given key is a spritesheet key
i.e. a key associated with loaded spritesheet, loaded in using
load\_spritesheet function.

Will return empty frame configs if key is not associated with
a spritesheet.

game.label: create_award
game.title: Auto-import from game
game.description:
#### create_award(x, y, award_key) → GameObject
Create an award using the key associated with the award.
The award key can be obtained from the Awards Hall or
Awards menu, after attaining the award.

Valid award will have an on-hover VERIFIED tag to distinguish
it from images created by create\_image.

If student does not possess the award, this function will
return a untagged, default image.

game.label: create_config
game.title: Auto-import from game
game.description:
#### create_config(lst) → ObjectConfig
Transforms the given list of pairs into an object config. The list follows
the format of list(pair(key1, value1), pair(key2, value2), ...).

e.g list(pair("alpha", 0), pair("duration", 1000))

game.label: create_container
game.title: Auto-import from game
game.description:
#### create_container(x, y) → GameObject
Create a container object. Container is able to contain any other game object,
and the positions of contained game object will be relative to the container.

Rendering the container as visible or invisible will also affect the contained
game object.

Container can also contain another container.

0, 0 is located at the top, left hand side.

For more details about container object, see:
https://photonstorm.github.io/phaser3-docs/Phaser.GameObjects.Container.html

game.label: create_ellipse
game.title: Auto-import from game

game.label: create_image
game.title: Auto-import from game
game.description:
#### create_image(x, y, asset_key) → GameObject | undefined
Create an image using the key associated with a loaded image.
If key is not associated with any loaded image, throws error.

0, 0 is located at the top, left hand side.

game.label: create_interactive_config
game.title: Auto-import from game
game.description:

game.label: create_text

game.label: create_text_config
game.title: Auto-import from game

font\_family: for available font\_family, see:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/font-family#Valid\_family\_names

align: must be either 'left', 'right', 'center', or 'justify'

For more details about text config, see:
https://photonstorm.github.io/phaser3-docs/Phaser.Types.GameObjects.Text.html#.TextStyle

game.label: create_tween_config

For more details about tween config object, see:
https://photonstorm.github.io/phaser3-docs/Phaser.Types.Tweens.html#.TweenBuilderConfig

csg.label: bounding_box
csg.title: Auto-import from csg
csg.description:
#### bounding_box(shape) → Function
Returns a function of type (string, string) → number, for getting the
specified Shape's bounding box coordinates.

Its first parameter must be "x", "y", or "z", indicating the coordinate axis.

Its second parameter must be "min" or "max", indicating the minimum or
maximum bounding box coordinate respectively.

For example, if a sphere of radius 0.5 is centred at (0.5, 0.5, 0.5), its
minimum bounding coordinates will be (0, 0, 0), and its maximum bounding
coordinates will be (1, 1, 1).
```
// Sample usage
const getter_function = bounding_box(sphere(silver));
display(getter_function("y", "max")); // Displays 1, the maximum y coordinate
```

csg.title: Auto-import from csg

#### group(operables) → Group
Groups the specified list of Operables together. Groups can contain a mix of
Shapes and other nested Groups.

Groups cannot be operated on, but can be transformed together. I.e. a call
like `intersect(group_a, group_b)` is not allowed, but a call like
`scale(group, 5, 5, 5)` is.

repl.label: repl_display
repl.title: Auto-import from repl
repl.description:
#### repl_display(content) → any
Display message in Programmable Repl Tab
If you give a pair as the parameter, it will use the given pair to generate rich text and use rich text display mode to display the string in Programmable Repl Tab with undefined return value (see module description for more information).
If you give other things as the parameter, it will simply display the toString value of the parameter in Programmable Repl Tab and returns the displayed string itself.

**Rich Text Display**

* First you need to `import { repl_display } from "repl";`
* Format: pair(pair("string",style),style)...
* Examples:


```
// A large italic underlined "Hello World"
repl_display(pair(pair(pair(pair("Hello World", "underline"), "italic"), "bold"), "gigantic"));

// A large italic underlined "Hello World" in blue
repl_display(pair(pair(pair(pair(pair("Hello World", "underline"),"italic"), "bold"), "gigantic"), "clrt#0000ff"));

// A large italic underlined "Hello World" with orange foreground and purple background
repl_display(pair(pair(pair(pair(pair(pair("Hello World", "underline"), "italic"), "bold"), "gigantic"), "clrb#A000A0"),"clrt#ff9700"));
```


* Coloring:
  + `clrt` stands for text color, `clrb` stands for background color. The color string are in hexadecimal begin with "#" and followed by 6 hexadecimal digits.
  + Example: `pair("123","clrt#ff0000")` will produce a red "123"; `pair("456","clrb#00ff00")` will produce a green "456".
* Besides coloring, the following styles are also supported:
  + `bold`: Make the text bold.
  + `italic`: Make the text italic.
  + `small`: Make the text in small size.
  + `medium`: Make the text in medium size.
  + `large`: Make the text in large size.
  + `gigantic`: Make the text in very large size.
  + `underline`: Underline the text.
* Note that if you apply the conflicting attributes together, only one conflicted style will take effect and other conflicting styles will be discarded, like "pair(pair(pair("123", small), medium), large) " (Set conflicting font size for the same text)
* Also note that for safety matters, certain words and characters are not allowed to appear under rich text display mode.

robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### addControllerToWorld(controller, world) → void
Add a controller to the world.

The controller is a unit of computation modelled after Unity's MonoBehaviour. It is used to
encapsulate the logic of the simulation. Controllers can be used to create robots, sensors,
actuators, and other objects in the simulation.

The controller should be added to the world using this function in order for the simulation to
access the controller's logic.

*\*This is a Utility function and should be called within init\_simulation.*

robot_simulation.label: createCSE
robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### createCSE() → Program
Creates a CSE machine as a Program Object. The CSE machine is used to evaluate the code written
by the user. The execution of the code will be automatically synchronized with the simulation
to ensure that the code is executed at the correct time.

The returned Program object is designed to be added to the world using addControllerToWorld.

**This is a Controller function and should be called within init\_simulation.**

Creates a cuboid. joel-todo: The dynamic version wont work

This function is used to create the floor and wall controllers.

The returned Cuboid object is designed to be added to the world using addControllerToWorld.

**This is a Controller function and should be called within init\_simulation.**

robot_simulation.label: createCustomPhysics
robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### createCustomPhysics(gravity, timestep) → Physics
Create a physics engine with the provided gravity and timestep. A physics engine
with default gravity and timestep can be created using createPhysics.

The returned Physics object is designed to be passed into createWorld.

**This is a configuration function and should be called within init\_simulation.**

robot_simulation.label: createEv3
robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### createEv3(physics, renderer) → DefaultEv3
Create an EV3.

The resulting EV3 should be saved to the context using saveToContext.

The returned EV3 object is designed to be added to the world using addControllerToWorld.

**This is a Controller function and should be called within init\_simulation.**

robot_simulation.label: createFloor
robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### createFloor(physics, renderer) → Cuboid
Create a floor. This function is a wrapper around createCuboid.

The returned Cuboid object is designed to be added to the world using addControllerToWorld.

**This is a Controller function and should be called within init\_simulation.**

robot_simulation.label: createPaper
robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### createPaper(render, url, width, height, x, y, rotation) → Paper
Creates a paper on the floor.

The returned Paper object is designed to be added to the world using addControllerToWorld.

**This is a Controller function and should be called within init\_simulation.**

robot_simulation.label: createPhysics
robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### createPhysics() → Physics
Create a physics engine with default gravity and timestep. Default gravity is -9.81 and timestep is 1/20.
A custom physics engine can be created using createCustomPhysics.

The returned Physics object is designed to be passed into createWorld.

**This is a configuration function and should be called within init\_simulation.**

robot_simulation.label: createRenderer
robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### createRenderer() → Renderer
Creates a renderer for the simulation.

The returned Renderer object is designed to be passed into createWorld.

**This is a configuration function and should be called within init\_simulation.**

robot_simulation.label: createRobotConsole
robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### createRobotConsole() → RobotConsole
Creates a RobotConsole for the simulation.

The RobotConsole is used to display messages and errors to the user. The console
messages can be seen in the console tab of the simulator.

The returned RobotConsole object is designed to be passed into createWorld.

**This is a configuration function and should be called within init\_simulation.**

robot_simulation.label: createTimer
robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### createTimer() → Timer
Creates a Timer for the simulation.

The returned Timer object is designed to be passed into createWorld.

**This is a configuration function and should be called within init\_simulation.**

robot_simulation.label: createWall
robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### createWall(physics, renderer, x, y, width, length, height) → Cuboid
Creates a wall. This function is a wrapper around createCuboid.

The returned Cuboid object is designed to be added to the world using addControllerToWorld.

**This is a Controller function and should be called within init\_simulation.**

robot_simulation.label: createWorld
robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### createWorld(physics, renderer, timer, robotConsole) → World
Creates a custom world with the provided physics, renderer, timer and console .

A world is responsible for managing the physics, rendering, timing and console of the simulation.
It also manages the controllers that are added to the world, ensuring that the appropriate functions
are called at the correct time.

The returned World object is designed to be returned by the init\_simulation callback.

You can add controllers to the world using addControllerToWorld.

**This is a configuration function and should be called within init\_simulation.**

robot_simulation.label: ev3_runToRelativePosition
robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### ev3_runToRelativePosition(motor, position, speed) → void
Causes the motor to rotate until the position reaches ev3\_motorGetPosition() + position with the given speed.
Note: this works by sending instructions to the motors.
This will return almost immediately, without waiting for the motor to reach the given absolute position.
If you wish to wait, use ev3\_pause.

robot_simulation.label: ev3_ultrasonicSensor
robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:

robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### ev3_ultrasonicSensorDistance(ultraSonicSensor) → number
Gets the distance read by the ultrasonic sensor in centimeters.

robot_simulation.label: init_simulation
robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### init_simulation(worldFactory) → void
Initialize the simulation world. This function is to be called before the robot code.
This function is used to describe the simulation environment and the controllers.

The callback function takes in no parameters and returns a world created by createWorld.
The world should be configured with the physics, renderer, timer and console.
The controllers should be added to the world using addControllerToWorld.
The world should be saved to the context using saveToContext.

robot_simulation.label: saveToContext
robot_simulation.title: Auto-import from robot_simulation
robot_simulation.description:
#### saveToContext(key, value) → void
Save a value to the context.

There are 2 important values to be saved. The world and the ev3.
The world needs to be saved in order for the simulation to access the physics, renderer, timer and console.
The ev3 needs to be saved in order for the "ev3\_" functions to access the EV3
